";More than 150 people died in last week's Kabul suicide blast, President Ashraf Ghani said as he opened multi-national talks on bringing peace.
Previous estimates said 90 people were killed in the bombing, the country's deadliest militant attack since 2001.
Mr Ghani's government has faced protests for failing to tackle the deteriorating security situation.
He told the meeting it was time for the Taliban to embrace peace or "face the consequences".
Representatives of 23 nations including the US and Pakistan, as well as the EU, Nato and the UN are attending the two-day meeting, which launches what is being called the Kabul Process for Peace and Security Co-operation.
UK Ambassador Dominic Jermey said it was "an important marker for each and every country in the region to show its true support for Afghanistan's aspirations for peace".
As it got under way a rocket struck a tennis court in the Indian diplomatic compound. Police said no-one was hurt."
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-40170596

I've looked at the trends in Afghanistan. Ghani has strong support from the United States and the international community. Although the situation in Afghanistan is bad, the trends are not significantly worse than 1 year ago. Furthermore, Ghani is full Pashtun, meaning he has level of stable support although he is at adds with Abdullah Abdullah's faction as part of the overall power sharing agreement. Short of assassination Ghani will remain President in 2017.
New Yorker "hit piece" back in July  remains relevant link here http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/07/04/ashraf-ghani-afghanistans-theorist-in-chief

lowering forecast on more research. The military situation is not catastrophic at the moment, and despite all the political chaos, I don't think Ghani is under serious threat (Abdullah much more so). https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/afghanistans-national-unity-government-rift-2-the-problems-that-will-not-go-away/

I think the current average of 25% is a bit pessimistic. As per the Afghan constitution, Ghani is supposed to serve a 5-year term. He also appears to have recieved a clear (if somewhat disputed) majority of votes in the 2014 presidential election (http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2014/09/ashraf-ghani-declared-winner-afghan-poll-2014921133512174572.html) , making him as legitimate a head of government as anyone. As far as I know there isn't a legislative mechanism to oust him, so the plausible "Yes" results here would come from a coup, a Taliban takeover, or Ghani dying.

1. July 1st 2017 will only be three years into Ghani's 5-year term.
2. He seems to be in good health.
3. He also worn a majority of the votes in 2014 elections
4. The problems in Afghanistan don't seem to be worse off than two years ago.
5. Presidents of Afghanistan always face an assination risk which is higher than the risk faces by most heads of state.
Taliban might be getting stronger. There are many ways to stop being president. A bullet might unfortunately be one of them.

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/09/gulbuddin-hekmatyar-group-signs-afghan-peace-deal-160922093420326.html
An unsigned agreement with the "Butcher of Kabul", possibly might lead the Taliban back to negotiations.
Afghanistan has many problems. Its president may be one of them.

Hmm. Hard to predict. It does not seem too likely to happen in the short term. My guess is that the fear of chaos will make the push for stability much more like to prevail. Still plenty that could go wrong. Also how likely is a president of Afghanistan to go out volountarily?
initial forecast; "predict no change" is a decent heuristic in Afghanistan, but plenty of uncertainty on a longish timescale

The next election is in 2019 and the current power-sharing deal is to cover only Abdullah's possible ascent to the Prime Minister role from his current executive position. Ashraf Ghani will cease to be President only when there's an election or a civil war, neither of which seems probable within the next ten months: outside powers are going to do whatever they can to prevent a civil war, and that's by its nature going to need the power-sharing agreement to hold, one way or another.

Taliban forces are already within a stone’s throw of the provincial capitals of Helmand and Kunduz Provinces, and are now within a few kms of a third, the city of Tarin Kot, the capital city of the central Uruzgan Province.
Security forces in Tarin Kot are predicting an imminent collapse of their defensive position along the city’s outskirts, noting that they haven’t gotten significant reinforcements to resist the Taliban advance, and that the troops remaining within the city are running low on food and ammunition.
http://news.antiwar.com/2016/09/07/taliban-offensive-approaches-central-afghan-provincial-capital/
